Graphical abstract Indium-Silicon linked: A recyclable well characterized hybrid catalyst has been applied in A3-coupling solvent free reaction under conventional and microwave heating to afford propargylamines in high yields. We describe the synthesis and application of a silica-xerogel-supported indium(III) composite (In/SiO2). Using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, by the first time it was possible to identify that the indium is bonded to the silica through covalent InOSi bonds. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms revealed that the In/SiO2 composite presents pores with diameters between 1 and 4nm, which allows it to be used as a heterogeneous catalyst. Thus, this composite was used as catalyst in an A3-coupling reaction with several aldehydes, amines and acetylenes, leading to the formation of propargylamines in good-to-excellent yields in solvent-free conditions, using both conventional heating and microwave irradiation (MW). The recyclability was evaluated under both conditions and no considerable reduction in the yields was observed after four cycles. Keywords Indium Supported catalyst Silica xerogel Multicomponent reaction Propargylamines 1 Introduction In recent years, In(III) salts have received increased attention as novel, green, Lewis acidic, water-tolerant catalysts for organic synthesis, showing high chemo-, regio- and stereoselectivity. Compared to conventional Lewis acids, In(III) salts have the advantages of stability, recyclability, operational simplicity and strong tolerance to oxygen- and nitrogen-containing compounds [1]. As homogeneous catalysts, In(III) salts have been widely used and investigated in cycloaddition [2], Friedel-Crafts [3], Mannich [4] and allylation reactions [5]; however, only a few examples of supported indium salts have been reported in the previous publications as heterogeneous catalysts [6]. The search for methodologies that are environmentally benign, practical and economical has become a target in the chemical community. In this sense, transition-metal-catalyzed multicomponent reactions have received great endeavors in the last decade and have been shown to be a powerful synthetic tool, as they allow the formation of several bonds including new CC bonds in an one-pot procedure, leading to highly functionalized structures from simple molecules [7]. Propargylamines have attracted much attention from organic chemists, as they are present in the structure of many natural products and potent drug molecules such as β-lactams, oxotremorine analogues, conformationally restricted peptides, isosteres, allylamines and oxazoles [8]. Also, the potential biological activity of propargylamines represents their major purpose against cellular apoptosis. The (R)-N-propargyl-1-aminoindane (Rasagiline, 1, Fig. 1 ), the most potent in preventing cell death [9], and deprenyl (Selegiline, 2, Fig. 1), used as an effective adjuvant to L-DOPA in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease [10], are representative examples. These compounds are versatile nitrogen-containing synthetic building blocks, largely applied in the synthesis of important compounds such as β-lactams, pyrroles, imidazoles and oxazolidin-2-ones [11]. Despite their importance, there are relatively few reliable methods for their synthesis, which usually explore the relatively high acidity of the terminal acetylenic CH bond to form alkynyl–metal reagents by reacting them with strong bases [11,12]. Nevertheless, these methodologies show some disadvantages, such as the requirement for stoichiometric ratios, high moisture sensitivity and strictly controlled reaction conditions. In recent years, enormous progress has been achieved on CH bond activation in terminal alkynes [13]. In this way, the synthesis of propargylamines using A3-coupling can be promoted by several transition-metal catalysts, such as gold [14], silver [15], copper [16], indium [17], and others [18], also including different metal nanoparticles [19]. The reaction proceeds through the direct addition to carbonnitrogen double bonds (preformed imines) or using one-pot multicomponent reactions. An interesting approach was recently described by Zhang et al. [20] developing a highly effective and efficient methodology using InCl3 as a catalyst for the multicomponent reaction through CH activation, leading to aromatic and aliphatic propargylamines with almost quantitative yields. With regards to these homogeneous systems, in most cases, they involve expensive transition metals or non-environmentally friendly compounds, which are often lost at the end of the reaction. In order to achieve the required recyclability of catalysts, several heterogeneous systems have been developed and successfully applied in catalyzed A3-coupling reactions [21–23]. Among them, silica is often employed, owing to its high surface area, good accessibility as well as its high chemical, mechanical and thermal stability [24]. Surprisingly, as far as we observed, there are few reports on the use of metal-supported catalysts for the synthesis of propargylamines [21(a)–(b),22b,23(c)–(d)]. It is important to note that only one example using an In(III)-supported catalyst in a one-pot multicomponent reaction has been reported [25]. In this work, silica-xerogel-supported indium(III) salt catalyst (In/SiO2) was applied in the one-pot A3-coupling under solvent-free conditions. An important feature of this xerogel is that the catalyst is not just embedded in the silica, but it is also covalently immobilized to the support. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of the use of wide characterized indium chemically bonded to silica as a catalyst for propargylamines. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Aldehydes, amines, acetylenes, tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS), InCl3 and other solvents were purchase from Sigma Aldrich and used without further purification. Carbon and hydrogen nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR and 13C-NMR, respectively) spectra were recorded on 300MHz Varian Inova 300 and Varian VNMRs 300 spectrometers. Chemical shifts (δ) are expressed in ppm downfield from tetramethylsilane as an internal standard in spectra obtained using CDCl3. Coupling constants are reported in Hz. Microwave-assisted reactions (MW) were performed on a focused microwave reactor (CEM) at indicated temperatures, using an irradiation power of 50W and a pressure of 100psi. XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) was performed in an Omicron-SPHERA station using AlKα radiation (1486.6eV). The anode was operated at 225W (15kV, 15mA). Survey spectra were recorded with 50eV pass energy. The In 3d region was recorded with a higher resolution (pass energy of 10eV). The detection angle of the photoelectrons, with respect to the sample surface (take-off angle), was fixed at 53° for all measurements. The C 1s signal from adventitious carbon at 285eV was used as an internal energy reference. All spectra were fitted assuming a Shirley background. Lines were fitted by 70% Gaussian+30% Lorentzian functions, with set values of full-width at half maximum for each line. EDS was performed for the In/SiO2 composite, which was dispersed on a double-faced conducting tape on an aluminium support and coated with a thin film of carbon, using Baltec SCD 050 Sputter-Coater apparatus. The images were obtained using SEM (scanning electron microscopy) on a Jeol microscope (model JSM 5800), connected to a secondary electron detector and an X-ray energy-dispersive spectrometer. The EDS (energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy) elemental analysis was obtained using seven measurements from different images, with magnifications from 4000 to 15,000×. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the In/SiO2 composite and pure SiO2 were determined at the liquid-nitrogen boiling point, using Tristar II Krypton 3020 Micromeritics equipment. The materials were previously degassed at 120°C under vacuum for 10h. The specific surface areas were determined by the BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller) multipoint technique [26] and the pore size distribution curves were obtained by using the BJH (Barrett–Joyner–Halenda) and DFT (Density Functional Theory) methods [27]. 2.2 Synthesis of In/SiO2 The synthesis of the In/SiO2 composite was adapted from procedures previously reported for other composites [25]. InCl3 (1.43g) was added to a mixture containing ethanol (5mL), water (2mL) and concentrated HCl (3 drops). The mixture was magnetic stirred until complete dissolution. Then, TEOS (5mL) was added and the mixture was stirred for an additional 15min. It was then stored for 5 days under ambient conditions, covered, without sealing, for gelation and solvent evaporation. The resulting solid was comminuted and heated for 24h at 120°C. Afterwards, the solid was extensively washed with ethyl alcohol and water, and finally heat-treated for an additional 24h at 100°C. A reference sample of pure SiO2, without addition of InCl3, was simultaneously synthesized in the same way. 2.3 General experimental procedure for the synthesis of propargylamines In a 10mL round-bottomed flask equipped with a magnetic stirring bar, aldehyde (1.1mmol), amine (1.2mmol), alkyne (1.3mmol) and 10 mol% In/SiO2 (0.050g) were added. The mixture was stirred for 12h at 70°C. After that, ethyl acetate (10–20mL) was added and the organic solution was separated from the In/SiO2composite by filtration. The solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and the residue was purified by column chromatography over silica gel, eluting with hexanes/ethyl acetate (90/10) mixture, yielding the products. All products are known compounds and spectral data obtained are in agreement with previous reports. 2.4 General experimental procedure for the synthesis of propargylamines under MW irradiation In a 10mL glass vial equipped with a magnetic stirring bar and containing the appropriate aldehyde (1.1mmol), amine (1.2mmol) and alkyne (1.3mmol), 10 mol% In/SiO2 (0.050g) was added and the vial was tightly sealed with an aluminum/Teflon crimp top. The mixture was then irradiated in a focused MW reactor (CEM) at 70°C, using an irradiation power of 50W and a pressure of 100 psi. After stirring for 10min, ethyl acetate (10mL) was added and the organic solution was separated from the In/SiO2 composite by filtration. The solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure and the residue was purified by column chromatography over silica gel, eluting with hexane/ethyl acetate (90/10) mixture, yielding the products. 3 Results and discussion The In/SiO2 composite material was synthesized using the sol–gel method. The amount of indium present in the In/SiO2composite was estimated using EDS elemental analysis, which was performed using seven different SEM images. The average result was 1.0±0.05mmol of indium per gram of composite. The In/SiO2 composite was submitted to XPS analysis. The In 3d and O 1s peaks are shown in Fig. 2 , and the binding energy values are presented in Table 1 , along with some already reported values for the In3+ ion, as well as chloride and oxide species. It can be observed that the In 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 peaks for In3+ in the In/SiO2 composite, appear close to the reported InCl3 values, but are slightly shifted towards oxide species. This result suggests that the In3+ ions are link with unsaturated oxygen and chloride forming OInClx (x =1 or 2), as already reported for the In/TiO2 composite, which is synthesized by the same way [28]. Additionally, the O 1s spectrum shows two components, one at 533.4eV in a major proportion that is compatible with the oxygen of SiO2, and a second minor peak that appears at 531.6eV. This minor peak presents an intermediate value between the reported SiO2 and In2O3 values (Table 1). It is important to point out that the position of the O 1s peak is related to the electronegativity of the element bonded to the oxygen. Silicon presents a higher Pauling electronegativity than indium (1.90 for silicon and 1.78 for indium). This difference is enough to result in higher 1s binding energy for oxygen on silica (ca. 533eV) in comparison with In2O3 (ca. 530eV). Therefore, the intermediate value of the minor peak (531.6eV), observed in the present work (Table 1 and Fig. 2), provides evidence that there is a fraction of oxygen atoms that are bonded to silicon and indium simultaneously, compatible with the SiOInClx structure. This hypothesis has already been proposed in previous report for silica–hafnia materials, where the SiOHf bond was detected in a similar way [29]. Textural analysis of the In/SiO2 composite and pure SiO2 is presented in Fig. 4 . The N2 isotherms (Fig. 4a) are of type I for microporous materials, as expected for materials gelified in the presence of HCl as a catalyst [36]. The BET specific surface areas were 424±15 and 493±20m2 g−1 for In/SiO2 and SiO2, respectively. From the BJH analysis (Fig. 4b), it can be seen that In/SiO2 composite shows small difference in the mesopore size distribution, compared with pure silica. The In/SiO2 composite presents a fraction of mesopores with a diameter between 2 and 4nm, whereas pure SiO2 should be predominantly microporous, having a pore diameter lower than 2nm. The appearance of mesoporosity in In/SiO2 is more evident from DFT analysis, presented in Fig. 4c, where it is clearly possible to observe that the In/SiO2 composite presents pores with diameters in the 1–4nm range. These results indicate that the presence of the InCl3 during the gelation process produces small textural changes in relation to pure silica. Therefore, the high surface area and pore size distribution of the In/SiO2 composite render it a promising material to be applied as a catalyst. Taking into account the textural properties of the In/SiO2 composite, its ability as a heterogeneous Lewis acid catalyst in promoting organic reactions was evaluated. As a test reaction, an A3-coupling reaction between an aldehyde, an alkyne and an amine was chosen. The products of this type of reaction are propargylamines, which are synthetically versatile, key intermediates for the preparation of many nitrogen-containing biologically active compounds. For initial studies, we selected the reaction of benzaldehyde (1a), pyrrolidine (2a) and phenylacetylene (3) (Table 2 ). As shown in Table 2, the influence of temperature, catalyst loading and reaction time were analyzed. In the first experiment, benzaldehyde (1.1mmol), pyrrolidine (1.2mmol), phenylacetylene (1.3mmol) and the In/SiO2 composite (10 mol%) were mixed together under solvent-free and atmospheric conditions at room temperature, and after 12h, no product was observed (Table 2, entry 1). Despite our initial misfortune, we decided to perform the same reaction using higher temperatures. When the reaction was carried out at 50°C, the product was obtained in 20% yield (Table 2, entry 2), and by changing the temperature to 70°C, the reaction proceeded smoothly and generated the desired product propargylamine 4a in 94% yield (Table 2, entry 3). Higher reaction temperatures also influence the product yields (entries 4 and 5), were a remarkable reduction on yield was observed. Additionally, by thin-layer chromatography (TLC), we detected that longer reaction times and higher temperatures led to the formation of a complex mixture of by-products. Finally, the impact of the In/SiO2 catalyst loading on the reaction efficiency was investigated (Table 2, entries 7–11). By decreasing the amount of the heterogeneous catalyst from 10mol% to 5, 2.5 or 1mol%, the reaction did not go to completion (Table 2, entry 3 and entries 7–9), and no product was formed in the absence of catalyst (Table 2, entry 11), showing that this parameter had an effective influence on the reaction course. Other indium salt, InBr3, was also used to produce a composite material and was also employed in this reaction, affording the desired product with a slight decrease on the reaction yield, when compared with the InCl3 analogous (Table 2, entries 3 and 10). After reaction conditions optimization, several aldehydes, amines and phenylacetylene were investigated to check the versatility of the protocol; the results are summarized in Table 3 . In general, all reactions proceeded smoothly with good yields. When different aromatic aldehydes were used, it was observed that the products were obtained in satisfactory yields, even when electron-withdrawing or electron-donating groups were attached to the aromatic moiety (Table 3, entries 1–3). Gratifyingly, alkyl derivatives are also suitable for the reaction, furnishing the desired products in good yields from valeraldehyde and butyraldehyde (Table 3, entries 6 and 7). By changing the secondary amine to piperidine or morpholine, a significant decrease in the reaction yield was observed and the desired products were obtained in 62 and 60% yield, respectively (Table 3, entries 4 and 5). These results are in accordance with the reduced amounts of reactive amines, owing to the stereoelectronic effects, thus making the nucleophilic attack of the nitrogen atom of the amine more difficult in forming the intermediate imine. Once again, less nucleophilic piperidine leads to lower yield when aliphatic aldehydes were employed. In recent years, it has been shown that organic reactions can be influenced by microwave irradiation (MW) [37]. In all these cases, the authors disclose that the use of MW irradiation can considerably decrease the reaction time, usually along with an increase in the product yields [1,38]. In this way, in order to develop an efficient protocol in terms of energy economy, we performed these multicomponent reactions under focused MW irradiation. Thus, the mixture of benzaldehyde (1a), pyrrolidine (2a) and phenylacetylene (3) was irradiated at different temperatures and times, using the In/SiO2 composite as catalyst (Table 4 ). As shown in Table 4, the reactions performed at 70°C and 10min under microwave irradiation(50W) furnished the propargylamine 4a in 97% yield (Table 4, entry 1). By decreasing the temperature to 50°C, lower yields were achieved (Table 4, entries 1 and 3). Besides, higher temperatures provided a slight lower reaction yield (Table 4, entry 2). In another set of experiments, we investigated the influence of the amount of catalyst employed. As observed under conventional heating conditions, the reaction yield drops by reducing the catalyst loading from 10 mol% to 7 or 5 mol% (Table 4, entries 4 and 5). A decrease in the product yield was also observed with lower reaction times from 10 to 6min (Table 4, entries 6 and 7). In order to check the versatility of the protocol, the activity of the In/SiO2 heterogeneous catalyst was then evaluated in a set of experiments under microwave irradiation, as summarized in Table 5 . In general, all reactions proceeded smoothly with good yields. A structurally diverse range of aryl aldehydes with electron-withdrawing or electron-donating groups, as well as aliphatic ones, were successfully employed in this reaction. Regarding the amines, the same behavior was observed in this protocol compared to the conventional heating method. The results depicted in Table 5 show that microwave irradiation is better than conventional heating (Table 3 and Table 5), furnishing the corresponding products in comparable yields and in very short reaction times. An important feature of supported catalysts is the possibility of recycling, which makes them an excellent choice, considering economic and environmental aspects. Thus, in an extension of this work, we verified the possibility of reuse the In/SiO2 catalyst in a model reaction (Fig. 3 ). To our delight the catalytic system was successfully recycled four times without significant decrease in chemical yields. These results are in accordance with the proposed structure, discussed above, where the indium species are covalently bonded to the silica matrix. Based on previous InCl3-catalyzed one-pot A3-coupling [17], a plausible mechanism for the formation of the product using In/SiO2 composite is depicted in Scheme 1 : the supported catalyst could first react with the terminal alkyne to form a stable In(III) alkynyl complex through a CH bond activation on the In/SiO2 composite surface. On the other hand, formation of the iminium ions from aldehydes and secondary amines could be accelerated in the presence of Lewis acid and HCl released in reaction medium. The resulting indium acetylide intermediate can subsequently react with the iminium salt generated in situ to give the corresponding propargylamine and regenerate the In(III) species. 4 Conclusions To summarize, we used the sol–gel method to synthesize an In/SiO2 composite. The In(III) ion is bonded to the silica matrix surface, forming a SiOInClx structure (x =1 or 2). To the best of knowledge, this is the first report of the use of a wide characterized indium composite, which is chemically bonded to silica, as a catalyst for the synthesis of propargylamines. The In/SiO2 composite shows a specific surface area and porosity that allows their application as heterogeneous catalysts in one-pot multicomponent A3-coupling reactions under solvent-free conditions with both conventional and microwave heating. The new catalyst afforded the products with good-to-excellent yields even when different aldehydes and amines were used. Another important feature is that high recyclability was achieved under microwave irradiation: after four recycles, without decreasing the reactions yields. Thus, our work describes an efficient and recyclable heterogeneous catalyst based on a silica–indium xerogel, as well as its applications in multicomponent A3-coupling reactions, in order to improve the synthesis of propargylic amines, taking into account green-chemistry statements. coredata.dc:description: We describe the synthesis and application of a silica-xerogel-supported indium(III) composite (In/SiO2). Using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, by the first time it was possible to identify that the indium is bonded to the silica through covalent InOSi bonds. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms revealed that the In/SiO2 composite presents pores with diameters between 1 and 4nm, which allows it to be used as a heterogeneous catalyst. Thus, this composite was used as catalyst in an A3-coupling reaction with several aldehydes, amines and acetylenes, leading to the formation of propargylamines in good-to-excellent yields in solvent-free conditions, using both conventional heating and microwave irradiation (MW). The recyclability was evaluated under both conditions and no considerable reduction in the yields was observed after four cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Covalently immobilized indium(III) composite (In/SiO2) as highly efficient reusable catalyst for A3-coupling of aldehydes, alkynes and amines under solvent-free conditions
